NEW COMMUNITY CENTRES
(Grant for furniture and equipment)


    1. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Prime Minister whether the grant of $24,000 for new community centres to purchase furniture and equipment will be substantially increased, as the amount is inadequate in view of higher costs resulting from inflation.

     The Senior Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Lee Khoon Choy) (for the Prime Minister): Sir, the People's Association is fully aware that the grant of $24,000 for the furnishing of a new key community centre is hopelessly inadequate at current prices, More than $100,000 is required to furnish a new key community centre. The People's Association will seek from the Government a substantial increase in the furniture and equipment grant.

Column: 106



     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, could the Senior Minister of State kindly enlighten the House as to when a positive answer can be obtained from the Ministry of Finance?

     Mr Lee Khoon Choy: I can only say that I hope that it will be very soon.

CHOICE OF SECOND LANGUAGE


    2. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education whether parents have any right in the choice of their children's second language.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Sir, pupils of Malay, Indian and mixed parentage are at present given a choice of Malay, Tamil or Chinese as their second language on enrolment. However, since the beginning of this year, all ethnic Chinese pupils are required to enrol for Chinese as their second language in Primary 1. An opportunity to switch to another second language is given at Primary 4 or at Secondary 1 only after the pupil has been given a fair chance to try CL2 and has shown that he cannot cope with the language.

Column: 107



    Apart from the fact that we want to encourage our pupils to learn something of their cultural origins through the second language, we know from our records that the passing rate for Chinese pupils is much better in CL2 than in other second languages. It is widely believed that ML2 (Malay as a second language) is an easy subject for non-Malays, but this is not the case. For example, in the 1979 'O' level examination, only 53% of the small number of Chinese pupils (705 to be precise) who took ML2 passed with Grade 6 or better, compared with 95% passes for Malay pupils. In 1980, the percentage passes in ML2 were 61% for Chinese pupils as against 99% passes for Malay pupils. These figures consistently indicate that ML2 is by no means an easy subject for Chinese pupils. In contrast, the percentage passes for Chinese pupils in the 'O' level CL2 examination in 1979 and 1980 were 80% and 84% respectively. One reason why Chinese pupils do not do as well in ML2 as Malay pupils is that they do not speak Malay as the home language. Even for those who do, the level of the home language is likely to be much more elementary than the standard of ML2 taught up to 'O' level.

VISUAL DISPLAY UNITS
(Effects on operators)


    4. Mr Lim Boon Heng asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour, with the increasing use of visual display units, if the Ministry of Labour will be undertaking a comprehensive study on industrial health related to the use of such equipment, and if the Ministry intends to issue guidelines for the protection of workers using such equipment.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Dr Wong Kwei Cheong) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Sir, visual display units (VDUs) have been introduced into industry on a wide scale in many countries during the last decade. They have only recently gained popularity in the Republic.

    Experience in other countries shows that, basically, concern about the use of VDUs on health revolves round radiation hazards and eye problems. In the case of radiation hazards, the Radiation Protection Inspectorate of the Department of Scientific Services conducted a test on VDUs in December, 1980, and concluded that they emitted "no hazardous radiation harmful to the general health of an operator". The UK Health and Safety Executive and the relevant authority of other countries like the US also hold a similar view.

    As regards eye problems, the UK Health and Safety Executive has concluded that, while for most people VDUs pose no risk to health, some attention should be paid to certain aspects of their use if eye discomfort is to be avoided. This organization as well as the US National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health have proposed ways to reduce eye complaints.

Column: 109



    There is, therefore, no need to undertake a comprehensive study on health hazards related to the use of VDUs. The Industrial Health Department of the Ministry will continue to monitor the situation regarding the use of VDUs. It will liaise with the Radiation Protection Inspectorate to ensure that radiation levels remain low. The Ministry will issue guidelines to industry to reduce complaints of eye strain in due course.

     Mr Rohan bin Kamis (Telok Blangah): Sir, would the Minister of State elaborate what these guidelines would be?

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: Sir, guidelines will be issued in relation to lighting, such as screen and character size, brightness and contrast, work station and general illumination levels, viewing distance and angle, and minimizing screen glare. Guidelines will also be issued in relation to ergonomic aspects, such as keyboard and screen heights, seat heights and leg-room. Guidelines will also be issued in relation to suitable work rest breaks as well as preplacement and annual vision testing.

HOTEL INDUSTRY
(Manpower shortage)


    5. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (a) whether the hotel industry is now facing a shortage of manpower; (b) how acute this problem will be by the late 1980s, taking into account the growth of the tourist industry and the construction of new hotels; and (c) what measures will be taken by Government to alleviate the problems.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Sir, from various sources, including hotels, the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board and the Singapore Hotel Association, the Ministry gathers that the labour shortage in the hotel industry is not acute. The shortages are mainly in occupations such as waitresses and chambermaids.

Column: 110



    To alleviate the immediate shortage of workers, the Government has recently reviewed and liberalized work permit policies allowing the service sector, including the hotel industry, to employ workers from traditional as well as non-traditional sources.

    Over the next five years, another 13,500 rooms are expected to be added and more workers will be required. However, over the long term, after the implementation of the wage correction policy, the industry is expected to introduce measures, such as computerization and mechanization to raise productivity and to economize on its use of labour. Nevertheless, the Ministry will continue to monitor the labour situation in the industry and will introduce remedial measures as and when required.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, taking into account that, up to the late 1980's, there will be an increase of 13,500 hotel rooms, in the opinion of the Ministry what would be the increase in the demand for the workforce? Secondly, would the traditional and, non-traditional sources of labour that we depend upon, be able to meet this demand?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Sir, according to the Singapore Hotel Association, an expected number of about 16,000 workers will be required, but this is a rather high figure because the staff to room ratio used is about 1.2:1. If we take the more advanced countries, such as the United States, Japan and even Hawaii, the staff to room ratio is about 0.5:1. If we assume that the hotel industry take heed of the Government's call to mechanize and computerize, and finally achieve a staff to room ratio of 0.5:1, then the present staff should be sufficient to cater for the needs of the future.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Sir, in view of the fact that hotels depend on the provision of good service to their guests, would it not be dangerous to rely on imported workers to solve the problem, without first ensuring that they are properly trained?

Column: 111



     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: First, I would like to stress that it is important for the hotel industry to mechanize, and through mechanization the unnecessary labour in the various sectors of the hotel industry will be released to perform work in areas where service is most required. On the other hand, by liberalizing the work permit schemes, people will be brought in to fill in the areas where chambermaids and waitresses will be used, and training will certainly have to be provided by the hotel if they want to remain viable.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, the Government has been concerned with the upgrading of the skills of our workers. To what extent does the Parliamentary Secretary think that the hotel industry, however it chooses to automate or upgrade by mechanization, would be able to produce the kind of skills that we require?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: If the hotel industry is interested in remaining viable, then I think it will surely have a plan to train its workers. In September 1979, the hotel industry itself carried out a survey of 20 hotels representing about 51% of the total workforce of the hotels and have come out with their own recommendations such as providing a career development to promising staff, conducting in-house training, improving meritorious and long service benefits and offering more incentives to attract part-time workers, and farming out certain services that could be farmed out, such as security and laundry.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Would the Parliamentary Secretary agree with me that a chambermaid using a broom and a chambermaid using a vacuum cleaner is still a chambermaid?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: When we talk about mechanization, perhaps it will be best for the hotel industry to seek its own advice. But when we talk about mechanization, we are certainly encouraging the hotels to mechanize in order to save unnecessary labour.

Column: 112



     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, before asking a supplementary question, let me express my thanks to the Parliamentary Secretary for making an attempt to reply. However, he himself has stated that there will be an increase of 13,500 hotel rooms by the late 80's. This means more than 100% increase when compared to the present number of hotel rooms in Singapore. Bearing in mind the fact that there would be competing demands from the other industries and also the fact that it is not always easy to solve the manpower shortage at the managerial and supervisory grades - at the moment this is a crucial problem - I wonder if the Ministry could consider having serious discussions with interested bodies, so that the private sector, the Government and possibly the Labour movement, could together look into this problem of labour shortage in greater depth.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Sir, I must thank the hon. Member for his concern, but may I just enlighten him on the latest survey results that we have received. In fact, this survey was done by the Ministry of Labour. In 1980, for instance, administrative and managerial workers totalled 717, out of which there were only two job vacancies. So the problem really is not that serious. There will be a few vacancies in each industry once in a while.

NATIONAL SERVICEMEN ON NON-MILITARY DUTIES
(Effects)


    6. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the Minister of Defence whether the deployment of national servicemen to do non-military duties like teaching and possibly construction work will have any effect on the mentality of the people towards national service; whether this move will dilute the fervour for national service which was so difficult to build initially; and whether this will ultimately affect the morale of national servicemen who may feel exploited at being asked to do a duty which is not related to the defence of the country.

Column: 113



     The Minister of State of Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to reply.

    It has been the practice of the Ministry of Defence (Mindef) to deploy national servicemen, who are not physically fit for strenuous combat duties, in non-combat supportive and administrative services in the Singapore Armed Forces.

    From time to time, Mindef receives requests from other Ministries for manpower assistance to carry out urgent assignments that are in the national interest. One such example is the recent request from the Ministry of Education for English-medium teachers to help the Ministry in alleviating its present shortage of English-medium teachers in primary schools. Mindef agreed to attach 48 of these non-combat fit servicemen to the Ministry as English-medium teachers on a short-term basis. The servicemen concerned were selected on the basis of their academic qualifications, interest and aptitude in teaching. Their participation is voluntary.

    As for the possible use of national servicemen in construction work, Mindef and the Ministry of Home Affairs, which is in charge of civil defence, have identified a need for servicemen with skills in the construction trades in the national civil defence programme. These skills are essential for excavation, damage containment, repairs, reconstruction and other related activities. Training national servicemen in the construction trades would, therefore, have direct relevance, in the overall defence of the nation. As the feasibility of such a scheme is currently under study, it would be premature to discuss it at this time. Details of the proposed scheme will be released when the study is completed.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon: Sir, will the use of national servicemen in the construction industry be on a voluntary basis too?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, various options are being looked into, and that is one of the possibilities which we will consider.

APPLICATIONS FOR HDB FLATS
(Number of withdrawals and changes to smaller units since price increase)


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board (i) how many applicants have withdrawn their applications for flats; and (ii) how many applicants have changed their applications from 5-room to 4-room or from 4-room to 3-room flats, since the increase in prices of HDB flats as well as the requirement to pay 20% down-payment upon application (pertaining to HUDC flats).

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, during the period 17th May to 30th June 1981, 260 applicants changed their applications from bigger to smaller flats. Twenty of them changed from executive flats to 5-room flats; 70 from 5-room to 4-room or 3-room flats; and 170 from 4-room to 3-room flats. These 260 applicants represent only 0.28% of the waiting list of 94,400 as at 30th June 1981. It shows that the overwhelming majority of applicants can afford the new prices.

    Over the same period, 129 applicants cancelled or withdrew their applications. This is, in fact, lower than the average of 150 cancellations over a normal period of 1 1/2-months.

    The Housing and Development Board cannot ascertain with complete accuracy the ability of applicants to afford flat prices based on the income declared in the application form. Invariably, the applicant's ability to pay would be under-estimated as there may be extraneous sources of finance, such as financial support from parents, or brothers and sisters, or from accumulated personal savings.

    The purpose of imposing a 10% downpayment on HUDC applicants is to weed out non-urgent or marginal applicants. Since the imposition, 1,543 applicants, representing 22% of the HUDC waiting list, have been weeded out.

Column: 115



     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, would the Hon. Minister for National Development agree with me that those 260 applicants who have changed their applications from bigger to smaller flats should not lose their priority as such?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, their priority will not be adversely affected as they will be allowed to retain their registration numbers.

INDUSTRIAL WORKSHOPS
(Improvement in design)


    8. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether he is aware that the industrial workshops built by the Housing and Development Board, like the three blocks in the Punggol Estate, are inadequately designed to meet the needs of trades like furniture-making, iron-mongery and small refrigeration plants, and contain a mixture of trades like mee and dumplingmaking; if he will request the HDB to look into the matter with a view to improving the design of such premises to ensure that the different needs are catered for and to separating industries like food manufacturing and other industries for health reasons; and, in future, if the HDB will relocate similar trades accordingly.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the size of HDB terrace workshops ranges from 88 sq. metres to 330 sq. metres to cater for the needs of the various types of industries, For health and environmental reasons, the food processing and manufacturing industries are segregated from the other industries. In addition, they must comply with approved standards set by the Government authorities.

    The terrace workshops at Block 12, Punggol Estate, are used exclusively to house food processing industries. Other non-compatible trades, such as wood-working, paper products, engineering and mechanical workshops, are located at Blocks 13 and 14, There is, therefore, no mixing of trades in the same block of workshops.

Column: 116



    These three blocks of workshops were completed in 1974 for resettlement of small industries which were affected by redevelopment schemes. Owing to business expansion, some tenants have found the workshop space too small for their needs and have applied for bigger units in other estates. Another 64 units of HDB terrace workshops in nearby Defu Estate are scheduled for completion in early 1982. Tenants in the Punggol Estate who require bigger workshop units can tender for one of these units when tenders are invited by the HDB.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, if that is the case, would the tenants in the three blocks of industrial workshops be given priority under the scheme in the Defu industrial estate?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, they will not be given priority. They will be treated as normal public tenderers.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, although the Hon. Minister has mentioned that the various trades are separated into three blocks, viz. Blocks 12, 13 and 14, is it not true that the three blocks are situated so close to one another?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, they are close to one another because they were built together and certain regulations have been complied with. One block is used for the food processing industry and the other two blocks are used for the other industries. This arrangement is acceptable to the Ministry of the Environment.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Location of families in the neighbourhood)


    11. Dr Lee Chiaw Meng asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board has

Column: 118

finalized the scheme to enable immediate families to live within the same neighbourhood.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the HDB presently operates three schemes to enable parents and married children to live near each other.

    The Joint Balloting Scheme permits parents and their married children on the waiting list for flats to be given priority in the allocation of adjoining flats or flats within the same estate. Since the introduction of the Scheme in August, 1977, 1,985 families have been allocated flats under the Scheme and another 2,046 applications are awaiting allocation.

    Secondly, families which already own HDB flats can take advantage of the Mutual Exchange Scheme to live in the same housing estate. Under this Scheme, lessees can mutually exchange their flats provided one party has occupied the flat for at least five years. Since July 1978 when the Scheme was introduced, 64 families have mutually exchanged fists. To further encourage mutual exchange, the HDB will be reducing the minimum occupancy period from five years to one year.

    Thirdly, tenants of HDB rental flats are granted priority for transfer of flats in order to live nearer to their parents or married children. A total of 448 families have taken advantage of the Priority Transfer Scheme for Rental Flats since its implementation in July, 1978.

     Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (Tanah Merah): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, would the Minister comment whether the Scheme that is operating now has been successful in bringing immediate families to live close to one another?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I think the scheme is reasonably successful. From the HDB records a lot of families still have their parents living with them. And this scheme is to enable families with married children who themselves are already separate family units, to live near one another. So the scheme can be considered to be reasonably successful.

Column: 119



     Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in his Chinese New Year message, the Prime Minister made certain suggestions on how the HDB could bring the immediate families to live together. Is the HDB considering those suggestions?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, yes, the HDB is considering those suggestions.

     Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, that brings me back to my original Question: Has the HDB finalized the scheme?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, as regards all the suggestions to bring the families together, whether they come from the Prime Minister, Ministers, Members of Parliament, or members of the public, the HDB has been carefully considering the various schemes. Those schemes that can be implemented immediately, the HDB has implemented them. As for those schemes that need time to formulate or if the schemes may give rise to problems or repercussions, then their implementation will take a longer time because further consideration will have to be given to them.

     Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, could the Minister give an indication when the scheme as suggested by the Prime Minister would be implemented?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the scheme will be implemented when it is ready.

    On the suggestion that clauses 26 and 27 provide for very lenient penalties, I suggest that one year's imprisonment is severe enough. If this penalty proves insufficient as a deterrent, then we can always come back to Parliament for heavier penalties.

    In the case of the Member for Kebun Baru, he was concerned about the courses being merely appreciation courses and that the National Computer Board would not conduct examinations which were professional in character. In my statement I have said that the Bill provides for the establishment of a Professional Examinations Syndicate. The provision should be adequate to ensure that the Syndicate would organize or the Board would organize professional examinations for computer systems personnel which would be recognized by the profession in Singapore.

    In the case of the Member for Telok Blangah, I think his general attitude was one of support. But there were some words of caution regarding the control of expenditure which may perhaps be wasted and also about skilled personnel not being mass-produced. These are words of wisdom which I will pass on to the National Computer Board. I think there should be no question that we want the National Computer Board established as soon as possible in order that our brain services can be developed rapidly.
